wider and embraces a concept of upbringing involving social and emotional development across denmark social pedagogues are the main workers in nurseries and other childcare settings and their training looked at is a new specialist teacher trained to work with children up to four in nurseries and other care settings babies and toddlers in day care and nurseries in new zealand and spain are overseen the start of the day a daycare inspector will warn today amid concerns that regular nursery inspections only give a snapshot of provision usually during main operating hours when the majority of children and staff and present the early years and schools watchdog ofsted conducted a special study by arriving at a series of nurseries as they opened in the morning as early as am in some cases alarmingly for parents several nurseries overrode their security systems in busy periods in the first hour of the day because they were short of staff to monitor the entrance in three cases inspectors were allowed into the nursery without challenge a lapse ofsted deemed unacceptable in one case unvetted staff took children to the toilet and in other instances staff were under too much pressure setting up the nursery or preparing breakfast to spend time with the children ofsteds study of the experiences of children in the first hour of the day revealed that in a third of nurseries that period or longer lacked planning and organization so that children were left without toys or babies strapped into highchairs with nothing to play with the inspectors who visited a cross section of day nurseries in september also found that in one in five there were not enough staff on duty at the start of the day to offer good care for children dorian bradley one of ofsteds deputy directors is expected to tell a conference on early years inspection and regulation in london today the shortage of staff meant there was too little time for children to feel settled or to reassure parents according to the findings in some cases children were left to cry because the phone had to be answered or staff tried to manage difficult behaviour by calling across a room rather than going across to sort out the problem ofsted did find some examples of good practice with the best daycare providers planning carefully for the difficult transition from home to nursery and ensuring they have extra staff on hand to support youngsters and their parents at the start of what is for many children a very long day in the paid care of others the findings suggest care at the end of an extended day will also be of poorer quality than during the core hours as staff are again taken away from children to clean up
